> Someone blogged saying this is not a good OO approach.  Not sure I
> understand what that means.  Simple equation: you have some CRUD
> operations and every other operations are dependent on these so all
> your other tests need to dependent the CRUD tests right.  Is this not
> pure OO?

This has nothing to do with "OO" or "not OO", but it does have to do 
with "flexible design".

If all your operations depend on concrete implementations of the CRUD 
operations, then your design is inflexible: it only works as long as you 
have the database attached. Instead, your business logic /could/ depend 
on an interface (I call it a Repository) that provides an abstraction 
for your CRUD operations. This way, you can test your database without 
relying on the database implementation of the CRUD operations. That 
design is easier to test and more flexible: I can replace the database 
with something memory-based for testing, or with something file-based 
for production. I could even use Prevayler.

References:

_JUnit Recipes_, chapter 10
My tutorial Test-Driven J2EE, which ran at SD West Expo this year
